conclusion: Use properties of light reflection and refractive index to solve the problem.
Identify given values: Inner radius R, Outer radius R' = sqrt(2)R, Refractive index n = sqrt(2).
Calculate angle of incidence using refractive index: sin(theta) = 1/sqrt(2), theta = sin^(-1)(1/sqrt(2)).
Determine angle of reflection: theta' = theta = sin^(-1)(1/sqrt(2)).
Calculate radius d of the light shield: d is the distance from center O to inner surface of hemisphere, which is R.
Use properties of hemispherical shell: d = R' - R = sqrt(2)R - R = R(sqrt(2) - 1).
Substitute given values: R = R' = sqrt(2)R, therefore d = R(sqrt(2) - 1).
Calculate final radius d: d = sqrt(2)R * sqrt(2) = 2R.
Since light exits from inner surface, radius d must be equal to inner radius R.
Final radius d of the light shield is R.
